Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling and Characterization of Transition Joints Made by Friction Surfacing Based Additive Manufacturing (FSAM)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this collaborative study is to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of modeling and control of Friction Surfacing-based Additive Manufacturing by creating a functionally graded, multi-layered weld transition joint between chrome moly steel (T91) and austenitic stainless steel (AISI316). The research approach will be to apply various nickel based alloy layers by friction surfacing, creating a smooth and gradual transition in physical and metallurgical properties to improve their creep life. The experimental program involves stress rupture and creep-fatigue tests to assess the creep behavior of the transition joints. The research approach for in-situ finite element modeling involves development of fine-scale crystal plasticity and homogenized anisotropic continuum plasticity models, which will help in obtaining the optimized process parameters for the fabrication of components using Friction Surfacing-based Additive Manufacturing.

If successful, this research will aid the accelerated deployment of T91 and AISI316 weld transitional joints for structures in emerging initiatives including boiler, nuclear and clean energy concepts. Through the finite element model development, not only can T91/316 joints be made, but a basic modeling and manufacturing infrastructure will be developed that can be applied to any application where transitional joints are needed between hard-to-process materials and/or materials where fusion welding produces undesirable intermetallic formation. The successful completion of this research will enable higher-temperature power plants to generate power 1) at lower cost 2) with lower greenhouse gas emissions and 3) in larger quantities resulting in a better quality of life. The results will also help make it possible to manufacture better performing and optimized components in a host of other engineering industries. The educational objectives of the proposal will focus on training of post-doctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students. Advanced Surface Technology course will be developed which will expose the students to the state-of-the-art advances in manufacturing technologies.

Institution.Name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this joint effort between the University of Utah and University of Louisville was twofold. First, to contain the problem of carbon diffusion between P91 and AISI 304/316 steels such that carbon diffusion doesn’t occur and second, to exhibit the feasibility of friction surfacing as an additive manufacturing technique in a multilayered fashion. The significant results obtained for this project via our tasks mentioned in our final report establish that both the objectives required to achieve the intellectual merit of this work have been established well. Moreover, the methods for computing residual stresses and distortions of this AM technique provide with methods which could be used in other metal melting based AM technologies as well such as Selective Laser Melting and Electron Beam Melting.

There are two researchers namely Javed Akram and Dr. Samuel Dilip Jangam, who got benefitted from this project apart from PI/Co-PIs at both the Universities. Javed Akram earned his doctoral degree (thesis in communication) and Dr. Samuel Dilip Jangam learnt the aspect of possibility to perform AM using Friction surfacing which is an extension to his doctoral studies where friction surfacing technique was used for material coating purposes.

Javed Akram finished his doctoral dissertation in Friction Surfacing based Additive Manufacturing (FSAM). During this project, Javed conducted experiments related to experimental optimization of process parameters and made significant progress based on deposition yields. This insight has led to initial sweet spots which have been locked down for the rest of the study to fabricate successful FSAM builds.

Dr. Samuel Dilip Jangam and Javed Akram have further performed EBSD studies on three principal cross-sections of the fabricated builds to inform and calibrate the model in addition to dislocation density based studies on electropolished FSAM fabricated samples before (virgin rods) and after friction surfacing which were conducted by the team. There were some delays in obtaining EBSD on one of the principal cross-section on a fabricated sample along with understanding the mechanism by which dislocation density measurements using TEM could be standardized.

The hurdles to perform creep testing and sheer costs of acquiring a machine beyond the budgets made available by the program forced the team to think in creative ways. Javed Akram built a machine with a dead weight balance which made it possible for the team to perform creep studies.

On the finite element modeling side, the initial delays in performing experiments also delayed the modeling schedule although the modeling activity has been continuously honed to accomplish more and more complex thermo-viscoelastoplastic phenomenon. Dr. Deepankar Pal, Co-PI was in-charge of the simulation development and he would like to thank his advisee, Dr. Nachiket Patil (PhD student at the University of Louisville) and Mr. Pradeep Chalavadi (volunteer contributions as an employee at 3DSIM LLC, Park City) to take immense interest and help him finish the numerical implementation and performing visualization of model predicted data.

The dissertation work by Javed Akram is an important contribution in Solid State Additive Manufacturing processing and metallurgical studies which were conducted in collaboration with Dr. Samuel Dilip Jangam.

To accomplish the broader impacts of dissemination of knowledge in student and professional engineering communities of interest, the co-PIs, namely Dr. Prasad Rao Kalvala and Dr. Deepankar Pal conducted various outreach events.

Dr. Prasad Rao taught a course on Selected Topics in Metallurgy with a specific reference to Weld Surface Engineering which relates back to the mentioned NSF project.

Dr. Prasad Rao verbally explained the scope of the project and increased awareness about FSAM by meeting a teacher and his 4 students who visited the Department from the Academy for Math, Engineering and Science (AMES), located at Cottonwood High School in Salt Lake City.

Dr. Deepankar Pal served as an organizer for a 1 day workshop on ‘Understanding Modeling and Simulation of Additive Manufacturing Processes’ organized by the AMC (Additive Manufacturing Consortium) and lead organizer for a 4.5 day long course on ‘Simulation of Additive Manufacturing’ organized by the TMS (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society).

Dr. Manoranjan Misra served as the Principal Investigator at the University of Utah facility and Dr. Brent Stucker served as the Principal Investigator at the University of Louisville facility. They provided guidance as needed. Dr. Khalid Rafi dropped out of the project due to the restrictions on his J1 visa. He now works at Underwriters Laboratories.


Last Modified: 10/29/2016
Modified by: Deepankar Pal

First, to contain the problem of carbon diffusion between P91 and AISI 304/316 steels such that carbon diffusion doesn?t occur and second, to exhibit the feasibility of friction surfacing as an additive manufacturing technique in a multilayered fashion.
